Stem: Students test how far toy cars roll after being pushed. Car A rolls 50 cm, Car B rolls 120 cm, and Car C rolls 200 cm. Which statement supports the claim that a faster car has more energy?
Choices: A) Car C had the most energy because it rolled the farthest, B) Car A had the most energy because it rolled the shortest, C) Car B had the most energy because it rolled in the middle, D) All cars had the same energy
Scenario Justification: Real investigation scenario with data about toy cars and distance. Students must connect distance rolled to energy, requiring reasoning about the relationship between speed and energy.
SEP Justification: Students analyze data (distance measurements) to support a claim about energy. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data and Engaging in Argument from Evidence.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding the relationship between speed, motion, and energy — faster objects have more kinetic energy. Applied in an investigation context.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — more speed (cause) results in more energy and greater distance (effect). Students reason causally about the data.
Key Recommendation: Good data-based question. Strengthen by asking students to predict how far a Car D traveling faster than Car C would roll, or to explain WHY more energy causes more distance.

Stem: Drop-down: Kira should make the track ___ to give the marble more energy.
Choices: taller / shorter / wider / narrower
Scenario Justification: Minimal scenario about a marble track. Students must connect height to energy but the reasoning is fairly direct.
SEP Justification: Students select a completion for a statement. Limited practice engagement — no data analysis or explanation construction.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that height relates to potential energy — a taller track gives more energy. Recall-level application.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Cause and Effect (taller track causes more energy) but in a trivial way.
Key Recommendation: Drop-down format limits depth. Redesign by providing data showing marble speeds at different track heights and asking students to identify the pattern and explain WHY taller tracks produce more energy.

Stem: A student places a cup of water in the freezer. After several hours the water turns to ice. Which statement BEST explains the energy transfer that occurred?
Choices: A) Cold from the freezer moved into the water, B) Heat energy from the water moved to the colder freezer air, C) The water created its own cold energy, D) No energy was transferred
Scenario Justification: Real observable phenomenon (water freezing). Students must reason about heat transfer direction — a common misconception area where students think cold moves rather than heat leaving.
SEP Justification: Students construct an explanation for an observed energy transfer. Engages Constructing Explanations. Must reason against the common misconception that cold transfers in.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that heat energy moves from warmer to cooler objects and that freezing involves heat leaving the water. Applied with conceptual depth.
CCC Justification: Engages Energy and Matter — energy flows from warmer to cooler. Also Cause and Effect — heat transfer (cause) leads to phase change (effect).
Key Recommendation: Good misconception-targeting question. Strengthen by adding a Part B asking students to predict what happens to the freezer air temperature and explain why, deepening the energy transfer reasoning.

Stem: A student holds a vibrating tuning fork near a piece of plastic wrap stretched over a bowl. Rice grains are placed on the plastic wrap. When the tuning fork vibrates near the wrap, the rice grains begin to move. Which statement about sound is BEST supported by this observation?
Choices: A) Sound waves can only travel through solid objects, B) Sound waves are caused by light energy, C) Sound waves carry energy from vibrating objects to nearby objects, D) Sound waves only move in straight lines
Scenario Justification: Real investigation with observable phenomenon (rice moving from sound vibrations). Students must connect the observation to a claim about sound energy transfer. Genuine reasoning required.
SEP Justification: Students evaluate claims based on observational evidence. Engages Engaging in Argument from Evidence — must select the claim best supported by the phenomenon.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that sound is a wave that carries energy and can cause objects to move. Applied in an investigation context.
CCC Justification: Engages Energy and Matter — sound energy transfers from tuning fork through air to rice. Cause and Effect — vibrations (cause) create sound waves that move rice (effect).
Key Recommendation: Strong phenomenon-based question. Could be elevated by asking students to predict what would happen if the tuning fork were placed farther from the wrap, or if the fork vibrated at a different pitch.

Stem: A student places a solar-powered fan in the sunlight and the fan begins to spin. When the student moves the fan inside away from the sunlight, the fan stops spinning. Which statement BEST describes the energy transformations that occur?
Choices: A) Heat energy to sound energy to motion energy, B) Light energy to electrical energy to motion energy, C) Sound energy to light energy to heat energy, D) Motion energy to electrical energy to light energy
Scenario Justification: Real observable phenomenon with a solar-powered device. Students must trace a chain of energy transformations. Genuine reasoning about the sequence of conversions required.
SEP Justification: Students construct an explanation for energy transformations in a device. Engages Constructing Explanations about energy conversion chains.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding of energy conversion chains — light to electrical to kinetic. Goes beyond single conversion to trace a multi-step transformation.
CCC Justification: Directly engages Energy and Matter — students trace energy flow through transformations. Also Cause and Effect — each conversion causes the next.
Key Recommendation: Good multi-step energy transformation question. Strengthen by asking a Part B about what would happen if the solar panel were partially covered, requiring prediction about reduced energy flow.

Stem: A student rolls a marble toward another marble sitting inside a circle on the floor. The first marble hits the second marble, and the second marble rolls out of the circle. What caused the second marble to move?
Choices: A) The circle pushed the second marble, B) Gravity pulled the second marble out of the circle, C) The air around the marbles pushed the second marble, D) Energy was transferred from the first marble to the second marble
Scenario Justification: Real observable scenario with marble collision. Students must explain the cause of motion through energy transfer rather than through common misconceptions.
SEP Justification: Students construct a causal explanation for observed motion. Engages Constructing Explanations from observation.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that energy transfers between objects during collisions and that transferred energy causes motion. Applied understanding.
CCC Justification: Directly engages Cause and Effect — collision (cause) transfers energy (mechanism) causing motion (effect). Also Energy and Matter — energy transfer between objects.
Key Recommendation: Good question with strong distractors targeting common misconceptions. Could be strengthened by asking students to predict what happens to the first marble's speed after the collision.

Stem: Car X is moving quickly and hits Car Y, which is sitting still. After the collision, Car Y begins to roll forward and Car X slows down. What does this observation show?
Choices: A) Car Y was heavier than Car X, B) Energy from Car X was transferred to Car Y during the collision, C) Car X lost all its energy completely, D) The ground pushed Car Y forward
Scenario Justification: Real observable scenario with car collision. Students must connect the observation of one car slowing and another starting to move to energy transfer. Very similar to Q6.
SEP Justification: Students interpret observational evidence to identify energy transfer. Engages Constructing Explanations from evidence.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that energy transfers between objects during collisions. Same concept as Q6 but with the additional detail that the source object slows down.
CCC Justification: Directly engages Energy and Matter — energy is conserved and transferred. Also Cause and Effect — collision causes energy transfer causing motion change.
Key Recommendation: Nearly identical construct to Q6 — both test energy transfer during collisions. Replace one with a question testing a different aspect of PS3-1, such as the relationship between mass and energy.

Stem: A toaster converts one form of energy to another form. What energy conversion occurs in a toaster?
Choices: A) Heat energy to light energy, B) Sound energy to electrical energy, C) Electrical energy to heat energy, D) Motion energy to sound energy
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Pure recall of energy conversion in a common appliance. No reasoning required.
SEP Justification: No practice engaged. Direct recall of energy forms in a device.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of energy conversion in a toaster. Recall-level knowledge.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged.
Key Recommendation: Pure recall. Redesign around a scenario: provide students with a toaster that is plugged in vs. unplugged and ask them to trace the complete energy pathway, including what happens to the heat energy after the toast is made.

Stem: A student builds a circuit but the lightbulb does not turn on. The circuit diagram shows an incomplete circuit with a gap at position X. Which object placed at X would complete the circuit and cause the lightbulb to turn on?
Image/Diagram Description: Diagram of an incomplete circuit with battery, wires, lightbulb, and gap at position X
Choices: A) Rubber eraser, B) Metal nail, C) Wooden stick, D) Plastic straw
Scenario Justification: Real investigation scenario with a circuit problem. Students must apply understanding of conductors vs. insulators to solve a practical problem.
SEP Justification: Students apply knowledge to solve a problem but the reasoning is fairly straightforward — metal conducts electricity. Limited practice depth.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that metals conduct electricity and complete circuits. Well-known classification.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Cause and Effect (conductor at X causes circuit to complete) but in a basic way.
Key Recommendation: Straightforward conductor identification. Strengthen by providing students with test data for multiple materials and asking them to identify the pattern that determines which materials complete the circuit.

Stem: Which of the following could increase the amplitude of waves in a calm pond? Select all that apply.
Choices: A) Rain falling into the pond, B) A sunny day with no wind, C) A leaf floating on the surface, D) Wind blowing across the pond, E) Rocks falling into the pond
Scenario Justification: Minimal scenario about a calm pond. Students must identify sources of wave energy but the reasoning is fairly direct.
SEP Justification: Students classify disturbance sources. Limited practice depth — no data analysis or explanation.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that waves are caused by disturbances that add energy to water. Applied classification.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Cause and Effect — disturbances cause waves — but in a basic classification format.
Key Recommendation: Basic classification of wave-causing disturbances. Redesign by providing data about wave heights from different disturbances and asking students to analyze the relationship between disturbance energy and wave amplitude.

Stem: Jennifer moves one end of a rope up and down to make waves. What happens to the wavelength of the waves if Jennifer moves the rope up and down faster?
Choices: A) Wavelength increases and fewer waves are made, B) Wavelength decreases and more waves are made, C) Wavelength stays the same, D) Wavelength increases and more waves are made
Scenario Justification: Real investigation scenario with observable wave behavior. Students must reason about the relationship between frequency and wavelength.
SEP Justification: Students predict outcomes based on understanding of wave properties. Engages Constructing Explanations about wave behavior.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding the inverse relationship between frequency and wavelength. Application-level — students must connect faster motion to shorter wavelength.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — faster motion (cause) leads to shorter wavelength and more waves (effect). Also engages Patterns — the frequency-wavelength relationship.
Key Recommendation: Good conceptual question about wave properties. Strengthen by providing a diagram showing the before/after wave patterns and asking students to measure and compare wavelengths, adding a data analysis component.

Stem: Where does the Moon's light come from?
Choices: A) The Moon creates its own light, B) The Moon reflects light from the Sun, C) The Moon absorbs light from Earth, D) Stars provide light to the Moon
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Pure recall about the source of moonlight. No reasoning required.
SEP Justification: No practice engaged. Direct recall of a fact about the Moon.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that the Moon reflects sunlight rather than producing its own light. Recall-level.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged.
Key Recommendation: Pure recall. Redesign by presenting a scenario where students observe the Moon at different phases and ask them to construct a model explaining why the Moon appears different throughout the month using the concept of reflected light.

Stem: A student looks at a nightlight through two cardboard tubes — one straight and one bent. Through which tube can the student see the nightlight?
Choices: A) Both tubes because light bends around corners, B) Only the straight tube because light travels in straight lines, C) Only the bent tube because light follows curves, D) Neither tube because cardboard blocks light
Scenario Justification: Real investigation scenario testing light behavior. Students must apply understanding that light travels in straight lines to predict an observable outcome.
SEP Justification: Students apply a principle to predict an outcome. Limited practice depth — straightforward application.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that light travels in straight lines and cannot bend around obstacles. Applied in a concrete test scenario.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — straight-line travel (property) causes visibility only through straight tube (effect). Basic application.
Key Recommendation: Good scenario but the answer is fairly obvious. Strengthen by adding a mirror inside the bent tube and asking students whether the light would now be visible and why.

Stem: A lost camper in a cloudy forest needs to signal for help. The camper has a mirror and a whistle. Which method would be BEST for signaling in this situation and why?
Choices: A) Use the mirror because light travels faster than sound, B) Use the whistle because sound can travel around obstacles like trees, C) Use the mirror because it reflects clouds, D) Use the whistle because it is louder than a mirror
Scenario Justification: Extended real-world scenario with constraints (cloudy sky, forest with obstacles). Students must compare light and sound properties in context to solve a practical problem. Genuine reasoning about wave behavior in different conditions.
SEP Justification: Students evaluate solutions based on scientific principles about wave behavior. Engages Constructing Explanations and implicitly Designing Solutions.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that sound waves can travel around obstacles (diffraction) while light cannot. Applied to a real problem with specific constraints.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — forest obstacles (cause) block light but not sound (effect). Also Patterns — understanding that wave types behave differently around obstacles.
Key Recommendation: Strong applied question with real-world constraints. One of the better items on this test. Could be elevated further by asking students to explain under what different conditions the mirror would be the better choice.

Stem: After running around the track at recess, Jordan notices that he is breathing faster and his heart is beating quickly. Which statement BEST explains this observation?
Choices: A) Jordan's lungs are working harder to get oxygen and his heart is pumping faster to deliver oxygen to his muscles, B) Jordan's lungs are tired and need rest, C) Jordan's heart beats faster because it is scared, D) Jordan's body is overheating and needs to cool down
Scenario Justification: Real observable scenario connecting exercise to organ function. Students must explain the purpose of increased breathing and heart rate during exercise.
SEP Justification: Students select an explanation for an observed phenomenon. The correct answer essentially restates the observation with some mechanistic reasoning. Limited practice depth.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding how the respiratory and circulatory systems work together to deliver oxygen to muscles during exercise. Applied understanding.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Systems and System Models — lungs and heart as parts of an interconnected system — but not explicitly required.
Key Recommendation: Good scenario but the correct answer is fairly transparent. Strengthen by asking students to explain what would happen if Jordan sat down and rested, and WHY his breathing and heart rate would change.

Stem: Two plants are shown. Which feature belongs to only one of these plants?
Choices: A) Bark, B) Leaves, C) Roots, D) Stems
Scenario Justification: Image-based comparison of two plants. Students must identify a structural difference. Minimal reasoning required.
SEP Justification: No practice engaged beyond visual identification. Pure recall/observation.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of plant structures and that different plants have different features. Basic classification.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged.
Key Recommendation: Pure identification question. Redesign by asking students to explain HOW the unique feature helps the plant survive in its environment, engaging Structure and Function.

Stem: A chameleon lives in a forest habitat where it climbs trees and branches. What body structure BEST helps the chameleon move through its habitat?
Choices: A) Long tongue for catching insects, B) Feet that can grip and grasp branches, C) Color-changing skin for camouflage, D) Large eyes that move independently
Scenario Justification: Provides a real organism and habitat context. Students must match a structural feature to a specific function (movement), though the answer is fairly direct.
SEP Justification: Students select a structure matched to a function. Limited practice depth — no data analysis or model building.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of structure-function relationships in organisms. Applied at the classification level.
CCC Justification: Engages Structure and Function — feet structure helps movement function. Basic but direct CCC application.
Key Recommendation: Straightforward structure-function matching. Strengthen by presenting multiple organisms with different foot structures and asking students to explain how each foot type is adapted to its specific habitat.

Stem: A frog buries itself in mud when the weather is dry to survive. What signal would cause the frog to wake up and become active again?
Choices: A) Increase in temperature, B) Increase in precipitation, C) Decrease in daylight, D) Increase in wind speed
Scenario Justification: Provides a real organism behavior context. Students must reason about what environmental change would reverse the dormancy, but the answer is fairly obvious given the setup.
SEP Justification: Students reason about an organism's response to environmental signals. Limited practice depth.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that organisms respond to environmental signals. Applied at a basic reasoning level.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — environmental change (cause) triggers behavioral response (effect). Basic application.
Key Recommendation: The answer is telegraphed by the stem — dry weather causes burial, so precipitation causes emergence. Strengthen by providing data about frog activity across multiple environmental variables and asking students to determine which variable most strongly correlates with activity.

Stem: A student on a field trip observes birds singing, smells flowers, and feels the rough bark of a tree. What body system transferred these observations to the student's brain?
Choices: A) Digestive system, B) Muscular system, C) Nervous system, D) Skeletal system
Scenario Justification: Provides a minimal scenario (field trip) but the actual question is pure recall about which body system processes sensory information.
SEP Justification: No practice engaged. Direct recall of nervous system function.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that the nervous system processes sensory information. Recall-level.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged.
Key Recommendation: Pure recall despite the scenario dressing. Redesign by asking students to trace the path of a specific sensory signal (e.g., sound of a bird) from receptor to brain, constructing a model of nervous system function.

Stem: A cat watches a mouse hole in a fence (1), then steps through the hole feeling the edges (2), feels the ground with its paws (3), rubs its fur against the fence (4), and hears a sound and runs (5). Which actions involve the cat using its sense of touch?
Choices: A) 1 and 2, B) 2 and 5, C) 3 and 4, D) 1 and 5
Scenario Justification: Extended real-world scenario with a sequence of cat behaviors. Students must analyze multiple actions and determine which involve the sense of touch.
SEP Justification: Students classify actions by sensory modality. Some analysis of each action required but it is straightforward classification.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of which actions involve touch sensation. Applied classification.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged beyond basic classification.
Key Recommendation: Despite the interesting scenario, the question reduces to identifying which actions involve physical contact. Strengthen by asking students to explain how multiple senses work together to help the cat navigate, engaging Systems and System Models.

Stem: A geologist found rock layers at a site. The bottom layer contains dinosaur fossils, the next layer up contains plant fossils, then a layer with seashells, and the top layer contains fish fossils. What can the geologist conclude about this area?
Choices: A) The area has always been underwater, B) The area has always been on land, C) The area changed from land to shallow sea to deep sea over time, D) The dinosaurs lived in the ocean
Scenario Justification: Real geological scenario with multiple fossil layers requiring sequential reasoning about environmental change. Students must interpret fossil evidence to reconstruct Earth's history.
SEP Justification: Students analyze fossil evidence to construct an explanation of environmental change over time. Engages Constructing Explanations and Analyzing/Interpreting Data.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that different fossils indicate different environments and that layers reveal change over time. Applied reasoning.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns — the sequence of fossils reveals a pattern of environmental change. Also Stability and Change — the area transitioned from land to sea.
Key Recommendation: Good fossil-to-environment reasoning question. Could be elevated by asking a Part B where students explain what specific evidence supports each stage of environmental change.

Stem: Maya is hiking near a cliff and observes rock layers. The top layer contains fish fossils, the middle layer contains seashells, and the bottom layer contains tree leaf fossils. Which is the most likely explanation for these layers?
Choices: A) An earthquake moved the fossils around, B) The land slowly sank and the water got deeper over time, C) Fish and seashells lived on land, D) The fossils were placed there by people
Scenario Justification: Very similar to Q21 — another fossil layer sequencing question. Students must interpret fossil evidence to determine environmental change. Redundant construct.
SEP Justification: Students construct an explanation from fossil evidence. Same practice demand as Q21.
DCI Justification: Same DCI as Q21 — interpreting fossils as evidence of past environments. Redundancy reduces value.
CCC Justification: Same CCC engagement as Q21 — Patterns of environmental change over time.
Key Recommendation: Nearly identical construct to Q21. Both test fossil layer interpretation for environmental change. Replace one with a question on a different ESS standard or test a different aspect of ESS1-1, such as using fossils to compare environments across different locations.

Stem: Over millions of years, jagged mountains have become smooth, rounded hills. Which process is MOST responsible for this change?
Choices: A) Erosion, B) Volcanic eruption, C) Earthquake, D) Flooding
Scenario Justification: Minimal scenario describing a well-known geological process. Students must identify erosion as the cause. Limited reasoning required.
SEP Justification: No practice engaged. Pure recall/identification of the process of erosion.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that erosion shapes landforms over time. Recall-level.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Stability and Change (landforms change over time) and Cause and Effect (erosion causes smoothing) but in a trivial recall way.
Key Recommendation: Pure vocabulary recall. Redesign by providing data or images of mountain erosion over time and asking students to explain what forces cause the change and predict future changes.

Stem: A river has eroded steep walls and carved a deep valley over millions of years. What landform has been created?
Choices: A) Delta, B) Canyon, C) Plateau, D) Sand dune
Scenario Justification: Minimal scenario describing a well-known landform formation process. Students must identify the landform. Limited reasoning.
SEP Justification: No practice engaged. Pure recall/identification of a landform name.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that river erosion creates canyons. Recall-level knowledge.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged beyond implicit recognition.
Key Recommendation: Pure vocabulary/identification recall. Redesign by providing a topographic map or cross-section data and asking students to analyze the features to determine what processes created the landform.

Stem: A student compares a map of earthquake locations with a map of volcano locations around the world. What do these maps show?
Choices: A) Earthquakes and volcanoes happen randomly all over Earth, B) Volcanoes cause all earthquakes, C) Earthquakes and volcanoes never occur in the same locations, D) Most earthquakes and volcanoes occur near the boundaries where continents meet oceans
Scenario Justification: Real data comparison scenario where students analyze two maps to find a pattern. Requires spatial reasoning and evidence-based conclusion.
SEP Justification: Students analyze and interpret data from two maps to identify a pattern. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that earthquakes and volcanoes cluster at tectonic plate boundaries. Applied understanding from map evidence.
CCC Justification: Directly engages Patterns — students must recognize the spatial pattern of earthquake and volcano co-location. Strong CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Good data interpretation question using map comparison. Could be strengthened by providing actual simplified maps and asking students to identify specific regions where both hazards occur and explain why.

Stem: Text in image - partial evaluation. Satellite/topographic map of Hawaii. A farmer wants large flat land for agriculture. Student must select the best location from the map.
Image/Diagram Description: Satellite/topographic map of Hawaii with labeled locations
Choices: Image-based choices
Scenario Justification: Map reading task requiring students to interpret topographic features. Limited scientific reasoning — primarily a spatial literacy task.
SEP Justification: Students interpret a map to solve a practical problem. Some Analyzing and Interpreting Data from the map.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of topographic features and their relationship to land use. Basic application.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Patterns — interpreting topographic patterns on a map.
Key Recommendation: Primarily a map-reading exercise rather than a science question. Could not fully evaluate due to image-based content. Consider adding an explanation component asking WHY certain landforms are better for farming.

Stem: Text in image - partial evaluation. Question content primarily in image format, minimal text extracted.
Choices: Image-based choices
Scenario Justification: Cannot fully evaluate without image content. Based on available context, appears to be a recall-level question about natural resources or hazards.
SEP Justification: Cannot fully assess practice engagement without complete question text.
DCI Justification: Likely tests a basic ESS concept at recall level based on grade 4 ESS standards.
CCC Justification: Cannot determine CCC engagement without full question content.
Key Recommendation: Could not fully evaluate due to image-dependent content. Recommend reviewing the original test image to complete this evaluation.

Stem: Text in image - partial evaluation. Not enough text extracted to evaluate question content.
Choices: Image-based choices
Scenario Justification: Cannot fully evaluate without complete question text. Assumed to be a standard-level recall question based on test position and grade level.
SEP Justification: Cannot fully assess practice engagement without complete question text.
DCI Justification: Likely tests basic ESS concept. Cannot determine depth without full content.
CCC Justification: Cannot determine CCC engagement without full question content.
Key Recommendation: Could not fully evaluate due to image-dependent content. Recommend reviewing the original test image to complete this evaluation.

Stem: Text in image - partial evaluation. Question content primarily in image format, minimal text extracted.
Choices: Image-based choices
Scenario Justification: Cannot fully evaluate without image content. Based on position in test, likely an engineering/design question at basic application level.
SEP Justification: Cannot fully assess practice engagement without complete question text.
DCI Justification: Likely tests basic ETS concept — defining a problem or identifying constraints.
CCC Justification: Cannot determine CCC engagement without full question content.
Key Recommendation: Could not fully evaluate due to image-dependent content. Recommend reviewing the original test image to complete this evaluation.

Stem: Text in image - partial evaluation. Question content primarily in image format, minimal text extracted.
Choices: Image-based choices
Scenario Justification: Cannot fully evaluate without image content. Based on position in test, likely an engineering/design question at basic level.
SEP Justification: Cannot fully assess practice engagement without complete question text.
DCI Justification: Likely tests basic ETS concept — comparing solutions or testing designs.
CCC Justification: Cannot determine CCC engagement without full question content.
Key Recommendation: Could not fully evaluate due to image-dependent content. Recommend reviewing the original test image to complete this evaluation.
